head.title: ROSAT Evidence for Intrinsic Oxygen Absorption in Cooling Flow Galaxies and Groups

meta.name: keywords

article.h1:
ROSAT Evidence for Intrinsic Oxygen Absorption in Cooling Flow
Galaxies and Groups

span.span: UCO/Lick Observatory, University of California at Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064; buote@ucolick.org

div.p: The existence of large quantities of gas that have cooled and dropped out of the hot phase in massive elliptical galaxies, groups, and clusters is the key prediction of the inhomogeneous cooling flow scenario. Using spatially resolved, deprojected ROSAT PSPC spectra of 10 of the brightest cooling flow galaxies and groups with low Galactic column densities we have detected intrinsic absorption over energies âˆ¼0.4-0.8similar-toabsent0.40.8RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.8\sim 0.4-0.8 keV at the 2â¢Ïƒ/3â¢Ïƒ2ğœ3ğœNUMBER:2 italic-sigma MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 italic-sigma2\sigma/3\sigma level in half of the sample. Since no intrinsic absorption is indicated for energies below âˆ¼0.4similar-toabsent0.4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4\sim 0.4 keV, the most reasonable model for the absorber is collisionally ionized gas at temperatures T=105-6ğ‘‡superscript1056italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT=10^{5-6} K with most of the absorption arising from ionized states of oxygen but with a significant contribution from carbon and nitrogen. The soft X-ray emission of this warm gas can also explain the sub-Galactic column densities of cold gas inferred within the central regions of most of the systems. (This could not be explained by an absorber composed only of dust.) Attributing the absorption to ionized gas reconciles the large columns of cold H and He inferred from Einstein and ASCA with the lack of such columns inferred from ROSAT .

Within the central âˆ¼10-20similar-toabsent1020RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:20\sim 10-20 kpc, where the constraints are most secure, the mass of the ionized absorber is consistent with most (perhaps all) of the matter deposited by a cooling flow over the lifetime of the flow. Since the warm absorber produces no significant H or He absorption the large absorber masses are consistent with the negligible atomic and molecular H inferred from Hâ€‰iâ€‰ and CO observations of cooling flows. It is also found that if Tâ‰³2Ã—105greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘‡2superscript105italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\gtrsim 2\times 10^{5} K then the optical and FUV emission implied by the warm gas does not violate published constraints. An important theoretical challenge is to understand how the warm temperature is maintained and how the gas is supported gravitationally, and we discuss possible solutions to these problems that would require fundamental modification of the standard cooling flow scenario. Finally, we discuss how the prediction of warm ionized gas as the product of mass drop-out in these and other cooling flows can be verified with new Chandra and XMM observations.

article.div: cooling flows â€“ intergalactic medium â€“ X-rays: galaxies

span.span: â€ slugcomment: Accepted for Publication in The Astrophysical Journal

div.p: The evolution of the hot gas in the centers of massive elliptical galaxies, groups, and galaxy clusters has been most frequently interpreted in terms of the cooling flow paradigm (e.g., Fabian 1994). However, the characteristic radially increasing temperature profiles and centrally peaked X-ray surface brightness profiles usually attributed to cooling flows can be successfully described by only assuming a two-tier structure for the gravitational potential (e.g., Ikebe et al 1996; Xu et al 1998); i.e., the cooler gas sits in the shallower potential associated with the central galaxy whereas the hotter gas sits in the deeper potential of the surrounding group or cluster. The two-tier structure is typically incorporated into cooling flow models (e.g., Thomas, Fabian, & Nulsen 1987; Brighenti & Mathews 1998), but since cooling flows are not necessarily required to explain the temperatures and surface brightness profiles of the hot gas why should they still receive attention?

Unlike the empirical two-tier potential model, cooling flows attempt to offer a nearly complete theoretical description of the time evolution of the gas properties. A cooling flow describes the dynamical evolution and the X-ray emission of the hot gas by considering the following simple picture for the energy balance of a parcel of gas. Since the parcel of gas emits X-rays it loses energy. As the parcel radiates it sinks deeper (i.e., flows inward) into the potential well of the system where it encounters regions of higher density and therefore higher pressure. Consequently, the gas parcel contracts but is then heated as the result of PdV work. This balance between cooling and heating is expected to apply over much of the cooling flow. Within the central regions of highest density this balance is broken as cooling overwhelms the heating leading to the key prediction of the inhomogeneous cooling flow scenario: in massive elliptical galaxies, groups, and clusters large quantities of gas should have cooled and dropped out of the flow and be distributed at least over the central regions of the flow.

This prediction has inspired many searches in Hâ€‰iâ€‰ and CO for cold gas at the centers of cooling flows, and all such attempts have either detected small gas masses or placed upper limits which are in embarrassing disagreement with the large masses expected to have been deposited in a cooling flow (e.g., Bregman, Hogg, & Roberts 1992; Oâ€™Dea et al 1994). If instead the mass drop-out is in the form of dust then current constraints on the infrared emission in cluster cores are not inconsistent with cooling flow models (e.g., Voit & Donahue 1995; Allen et al 2000b). But cooling flows are not required to explain the infrared data in clusters (Lester et al, 1995) and individual elliptical galaxies (Tsai & Mathews, 1996).

The case for mass drop-out received a substantial boost with the discovery of intrinsic soft X-ray absorption in the Einstein spectral data of cooling flow clusters (White et al 1991; Johnstone et al 1992). The Einstein results have been verified with multitemperature models of the ASCA spectral data of clusters (Fabian et al 1994; Allen et al 2000b), elliptical galaxies, and groups (Buote & Fabian 1998; Buote 1999, 2000a; Allen et al 2000a). If the soft X-ray absorption is interpreted as cold gas then the large intrinsic column densities of cold H suggested by the Einstein and ASCA observations still suffer from the tremendous disagreement with the Hâ€‰iâ€‰ and CO observations noted above. The Einstein and ASCA results appear even more suspect when considering that in systems with low Galactic columns (where any intrinsic absorption should be easier to detect) no significant excess absorption from cold gas is ever found with the ROSAT PSPC which should be more sensitive to the absorption because of its softer bandpass, 0.1-2.4 keV (e.g., David et al 1994; Jones et al 1997; Briel & Henry 1996).

We have re-examined the ROSAT PSPC data of cooling flows to search for evidence of intrinsic soft X-ray absorption and in particular have allowed for the possibility that the absorber is not cold. Previously in Buote (2000c; hereafter PAPER2) we have presented temperature and metallicity profiles of the hot gas in 10 of the brightest cooling flow galaxies and groups inferred from deprojection analysis of the PSPC data. We refer the reader to that paper for details on the data reduction and deprojection procedure.

In this paper we present the absorption profiles of the 10 galaxies and groups, each of which have low Galactic column densities (see Table 1 of PAPER2). Partial results for two systems analyzed in the present paper (NGC 1399 and 5044) also appear with results for the cluster A1795 in Buote (2000b; hereafter PAPER1). In Â§2 we describe the models used to parameterize the soft X-ray absorption. We present the radial absorption profiles for a standard absorber model with solar abundances in Â§3.1. The effects of partial covering and the sensitivity of the results to the bandpass are discussed in Â§3.2 and Â§3.3. The results of modeling the absorption with an oxygen edge are presented in Â§3.4. In Â§3.6 we consider multiphase models such as cooling flows (Â§3.6.1). Evidence for emission from a warm gaseous component is described in Â§3.6.3. We demonstrate the consistency of the ROSAT and ASCA absorption measurements in Â§4. In Â§5 we discuss in detail the implications of our absorption measurements for the physical state of the absorber, the cooling flow scenario, observations at other wavelengths, and theoretical models. Finally, in Â§6 we present our conclusions and discuss prospects for verifying our prediction of warm ionized gas in cooling flows with future X-ray observations.

As discussed in PAPER2 we use the MEKAL plasma code to represent the emission from a single temperature component of hot gas. Because of the limited energy resolution of ROSAT â€‰ we initially focus on a â€œsingle phaseâ€ representation of the hot gas such that a single temperature component exists within each three-dimensional radial annulus. Multiphase models are examined in Â§3.6.

It is standard practice to represent the soft X-ray absorption arising from the Milky Way by material with solar abundances distributed as a foreground screen at zero redshift. In this standard absorption model the X-ray flux is diminished according to Aâ¢(E)=expâ¡(-NHâ¢Ïƒâ¢(E))ğ´ğ¸subscriptğ‘Hğœğ¸italic-A OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-sigma OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:) CLOSE:)A(E)=\exp(-\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\sigma(E)), where NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ is the hydrogen column density and Ïƒâ¢(E)ğœğ¸italic-sigma OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:)\sigma(E) is the energy-dependent photo-electric absorption cross section for an absorber with solar abundances. Since the redshifts are small for the objects in our sample any absorption in excess of the Galactic value indicated by the standard model is essentially that of an intrinsic absorber with f=1ğ‘“1italic-f RELOP:equals NUMBER:1f=1 placed in front of the source. We discuss the effects of f<1ğ‘“1italic-f RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1f<1 in Â§3.2.

To facilitate a consistent comparison to the standard absorber model we place this edge in front of the source, and thus Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau is also measured as a function of two-dimensional radius, Rğ‘…italic-RR, on the sky. Models with f<1ğ‘“1italic-f RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1f<1 behave similarly to the solar-abundance absorber (Â§3.2).

The photo-electric absorption cross sections used in this paper are given by BaluciÅ„ska-Church & McCammon (1992). Although Arabadjis & Bregman (1999) point out that the He cross section at 0.15 keV is in error by 13%, since we analyze E>0.2ğ¸0.2italic-E RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0.2E>0.2 keV we find that our fits do not change when using the Morrison & McCammon (1983) cross sections which have the correct He value. Further details on the spectral models used in the analysis are given in PAPER2.

div.p: Following PAPER2 we plot in Figures 1-4 the radial profiles of the column density and oxygen edge optical depth obtained from the deprojection analysis according to the number of annuli for which useful constraints on the parameters were obtained. This categorizes the systems essentially according to the S/N of the data. We refer the reader to PAPER2 for the temperature and metallicity profiles corresponding to these models.

In several cases the column densities and optical depths could not be constrained in the outermost annuli. Owing to the nature of the deprojection method large errors in the outer annuli can significantly bias the results for nearby inner annuli. Hence, in some systems we fixed the column densities to their nominal Galactic values or the edge optical depths to zero in the relevant outer annuli.

We begin by examining the spectral fits using the standard absorption model of a foreground screen (z=0)ğ‘§0OPEN:( italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(z=0) with solar abundances. The left panels of Figures 1-4 show NHâ¢(R)subscriptğ‘Hğ‘…italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(R) obtained from spectral fits over the energy range 0.2-2.2 keV. Our column density profiles are consistent with those presented in previous ROSAT studies (Forman et al 1993; David et al 1994; Trinchieri et al 1994; Kim & Fabbiano 1995; Jones et al 1997; Trinchieri et al 1997; Buote 1999) after accounting for the different plasma codes and solar abundances used.

The column densities are always within a factor of âˆ¼2similar-toabsent2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2\sim 2 of the Galactic value (NHGalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}), though in most cases NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ decreases as Rğ‘…italic-RR decreases such that NH<NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}<\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} at small Rğ‘…italic-RR. The quality of the fits for four of these systems is also formally poor (P<0.01)ğ‘ƒ0.01OPEN:( italic-P RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.01 CLOSE:)(P<0.01) in the central 1â¢â€²1â€²NUMBER:1 â€²1\arcmin bin (Table 1), and for several objects in the sample the metallicities are very large and very inconsistent with all ASCA studies (see PAPER2).111Here Pğ‘ƒitalic-PP represents the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} null hypothesis probability under the assumption of gaussian random errors. We discuss the suitability of this approximation for interpreting goodness of fit in section 3.4 of PAPER2. Since NHâˆ¼NHGalsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\sim\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} in the outer radii the observation that NH<NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}<\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} at small Rğ‘…italic-RR indicates that, whatever the origin of the deficit, it must be intrinsic to the source. (We provide an explanation in Â§3.6.3.)

The approximately Galactic columns are wholly inconsistent with the large excess columns inferred from multitemperature models of the spatially integrated ASCA spectral data of these systems (Buote & Fabian 1998; Buote 1999, 2000a; Allen et al 2000a). We now address the origin of this inconsistency.

It has been suggested that the reason why analyses with the PSPC do not infer large excess column densities for cluster cooling flows is that the standard foreground model used above systematically underestimates the true column intrinsic to the system (Allen & Fabian 1996; Sarazin, Wise, & Markevitch 1998). However, in PAPER1 we have tested this hypothesis for NGC 1399 and 5044 (and the cluster A1795) using our deprojection code. We find that the hot gas within the central r=1â¢â€²ğ‘Ÿ1â€²italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²r=1\arcmin (3D) cannot be absorbed very differently from the gas projected from larger radii because their spectral shapes for energies below âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV are very similar. If we do assume an absorber with covering factor f=0.5ğ‘“0.5italic-f RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5f=0.5 we obtain an excess column Î”â¢NH=0Î”subscriptğ‘H0Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}=0 at best fit and Î”â¢NH<NHGalÎ”subscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalDelta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}<\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} at >90%absentpercent90RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:90 POSTFIX:percent>90\% confidence for NGC 1399 and 5044. (Note that the f=0.5ğ‘“0.5italic-f RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5f=0.5 model implies a flat absorbing screen that bisects the source so that the 2D and 3D radii are equal, and thus the values of Î”â¢NHÎ”subscriptğ‘HDelta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}} quoted do refer to quantities within the 3D radius r=1â¢â€²ğ‘Ÿ1â€²italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²r=1\arcmin.)

Entirely analogous results are obtained for the other systems in our sample. We mention that partial covering models never improve the fits over the f=1ğ‘“1italic-f RELOP:equals NUMBER:1f=1 case. The only effect is that somewhat larger columns are generally allowed; e.g., for f=0.5ğ‘“0.5italic-f RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5f=0.5 the implied upper limits for the excess columns are typically a factor of 20%-40% larger than for f=1ğ‘“1italic-f RELOP:equals NUMBER:1f=1.

Hence, as in PAPER1 we conclude that models with f<1ğ‘“1italic-f RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1f<1 cannot account for (1) the large excess columns inferred from ASCA , (2) the sub-Galactic columns and poor fits obtained for several systems in the central 1â¢â€²1â€²NUMBER:1 â€²1\arcmin, or as we now discuss (3) the sensitivity of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ to the lower energy boundary of the bandpass.

In this case the fitted column density is NHâˆ¼15â¢NHGalsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘H15superscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:15 italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\sim 15\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}}; i.e., when Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}=0.5 keV the standard absorber model predicts that there should be negligible emission at lower energies in conflict with the observation.

div.p: Thus far we have shown (and confirmed previous results) that the ROSAT PSPC does not indicate the presence of excess absorbing material arising from cold gas intrinsic to the galaxy or group. In Figure 5 (Left) we display the ROSAT PSPC spectrum of NGC 1399 within the central arcminute along with the best-fitting plasma model modified by a standard absorber with NH=NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}=\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}}. The simple model provides a good visual fit to these data as well as a formally acceptable fit (Ï‡2=107superscriptğœ’2107italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:107\chi^{2}=107 for 97 dof and P=0.23ğ‘ƒ0.23italic-P RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.23P=0.23).

However, the evidence for intrinsic soft X-ray absorption from cold gas in galaxies, groups, and clusters from the Einstein SSS and the ASCA SIS is obtained with data restricted to energies above âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV because lower energies reside outside the bandpasses of those instruments. Let us examine what happens to the spectral fits of the PSPC data of NGC 1399 within the central arcminute if instead we raise the lower energy limit of the bandpass, Eminsubscriptğ¸minitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{\rm min}, to a value near 0.5 keV comparable to ASCA and Einstein , and we allow NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ to be a free parameter.

We find that when Eminâ‰ˆ0.2-0.3subscriptğ¸min0.20.3italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.3\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}\approx 0.2-0.3 keV we obtain fits essentially as indicated in Figure 5 (Left) with NHâ‰ˆNHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\approx\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}}. We see a noticeable change near Emin=0.4subscriptğ¸min0.4italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}=0.4 keV when the fitted column density increases to NHâ‰ˆ2â¢NHGalsubscriptğ‘H2superscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2 italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\approx 2\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}}. A dramatic increase occurs near Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}=0.5 keV which we show in Figure 5 (Right). The best-fitting model gives NHâ‰ˆ15â¢NHGalsubscriptğ‘H15superscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:15 italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\approx 15\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} when data below 0.5 keV are excluded from the fits: the standard absorber model when Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}=0.5 keV predicts that there should be negligible emission at lower energies in clear conflict with the data for Eâˆ¼0.2-0.3similar-toğ¸0.20.3italic-E RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.3E\sim 0.2-0.3 keV. The large column density obtained when Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}=0.5 keV is similar to the large value inferred from ASCA with two-temperature or cooling flow models (see Â§5 in Buote 1999).

For larger values of Eminsubscriptğ¸minitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{\rm min}â€‰ we find that NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ does not change significantly within the uncertainties. The statistical uncertainties on the fitted spectral parameters increase with increasing Eminsubscriptğ¸minitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{\rm min}â€‰ since the degrees of freedom decrease as the lower energy data are ignored.

In the middle panels of Figures 1-4 we plot NHâ¢(R)subscriptğ‘Hğ‘…italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(R) for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 keV. The character of the NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ profiles for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 keV is entirely different from the previous Emin=0.2subscriptğ¸min0.2italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2E_{\rm min}=0.2 keV case for half of the sample: NGC 507, 1399, 4472, 4649, and 5044. In these systems NHâ¢(R)subscriptğ‘Hğ‘…italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(R) for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 is consistent with the Galactic values in the outermost annuli and increases as Rğ‘…italic-RR decreases until (except for NGC 4472) it reaches a value consistent with a maximum for Râˆ¼1â¢â€²similar-toğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 â€²R\sim 1\arcmin. For the other five galaxies the constraints are too poor to discern a trend, though within the large errors their profiles are consistent with increasing as Râ†’0â†’ğ‘…0italic-R ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:0R\rightarrow 0.

The excess column densities inferred when Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 keV are most significant for NGC 1399. The lower limits within R=1â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²R=1\arcmin are 8Ã—10208superscript1020NUMBER:8 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end8\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} and 3Ã—10203superscript1020NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} at 95% and 99% confidence respectively which are factors of â‰ˆ6absent6RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:6\approx 6 and 3 larger than the Galactic value. Also within R=1â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²R=1\arcmin for NGC 507 we obtain 95%/99% lower limits of 8/6Ã—102086superscript1020NUMBER:8 MULOP:divide NUMBER:6 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end8/6\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} compared to the adopted Galactic value of 5.2Ã—10205.2superscript1020NUMBER:5.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5.2\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}. The most significant measurement for NGC 5044 is within the R=1â¢â€²-2â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²2â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€² ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 â€²R=1\arcmin-2\arcmin annulus where we find that NH>NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}>\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} at the 95% confidence level.

In order to obtain measurements of the intrinsic absorption at a higher significance level we must include the data below 0.5 keV. This requires a more appropriate model of the intrinsic absorption that does not conflict with the emission at lower energies which we now consider.

Since we find that NHâ¢(Emin)â‰ˆcâ¢oâ¢nâ¢sâ¢tâ¢aâ¢nâ¢tsubscriptğ‘Hsubscriptğ¸minğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals italic-c italic-o italic-n italic-s italic-t italic-a italic-n italic-t\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(E_{\rm min})\approx constant for Eminâ‰³0.5greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}\gtrsim 0.5 keV, the portion of the spectrum responsible for the excess absorption must be near 0.5 keV. Considering the PSPC resolution [Î”â¢E/E=0.43â¢(E/0.93â¢keV)-0.5Î”ğ¸ğ¸0.43superscriptğ¸0.93keV0.5Delta italic-E MULOP:divide italic-E RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.43 OPEN:( italic-E MULOP:divide NUMBER:0.93 keV CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta E/E=0.43(E/0.93\rm keV)^{-0.5}] and effective area this translates to energies âˆ¼0.4-0.7similar-toabsent0.40.7RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.7\sim 0.4-0.7 keV. The dominant spectral features in both absorption and emission over this energy range are due to oxygen, though ionized carbon and nitrogen can contribute as well (see Â§5.2).

Since the PSPC data cannot distinguish between a single edge and multiple edges, we parameterize the intrinsic absorption with a single absorption edge at 0.532 keV (rest frame) corresponding to cold atomic oxygen (Oâ€‰i). In the right columns of Figures 1-4 we plot the optical depth profiles, Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R), for the Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edge obtained from fits with Emin=0.2subscriptğ¸min0.2italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2\hbox{{$E_{\rm min}$}}=0.2 keV.

For every system we find that the shape of Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R) is very similar to that of NHâ¢(R)subscriptğ‘Hğ‘…italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(R) for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 for the standard absorber. Moreover, for those systems where NHâ‰«NHGalmuch-greater-thansubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-greater-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\gg\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 we find that Ï„â¢(R)â‰²0.1less-than-or-similar-toğœğ‘…0.1italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.1\tau(R)\lesssim 0.1 in the outermost annuli and increases to Ï„â¢(R)âˆ¼1similar-toğœğ‘…1italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\tau(R)\sim 1 in the central bin. Therefore, the single oxygen edge reproduces all of the excess absorption indicated by NHâ¢(R)subscriptğ‘Hğ‘…italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(R) for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 for the standard absorber model.

The fits within the central radial bin are clearly improved for several systems when the single oxygen edge is added, even though in some cases the quality of the fit is already judged to be formally acceptable (null hypothesis Pâ‰³0.1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘ƒ0.1italic-P RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:0.1P\gtrsim 0.1) without the edge. The improvement in the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} fit is quantified by the F Test (e.g., Bevington 1969), and in Table 1 for each galaxy and group we give the F-Test probability, Pâ¢(F)ğ‘ƒğ¹italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:)P(F), which compares the fits with and without the edge; i.e., Pâ¢(F)â‰ª1much-less-thanğ‘ƒğ¹1italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1P(F)\ll 1 indicates the edge improves the fit significantly.

Concentrating on models with the standard absorber with NH=NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}=\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} we see in Table 1 the largest improvements exist for NGC 5044 (Pâ¢(F)=9.2Ã—10-10ğ‘ƒğ¹9.2superscript1010italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:9.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(F)=9.2\times 10^{-10}), NGC 4472 (Pâ¢(F)=8.8Ã—10-8ğ‘ƒğ¹8.8superscript108italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:8.8 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(F)=8.8\times 10^{-8}), and NGC 1399 (Pâ¢(F)=1.3Ã—10-6ğ‘ƒğ¹1.3superscript106italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(F)=1.3\times 10^{-6}). A very significant improvement is also found for NGC 4649 (Pâ¢(F)=3.2Ã—10-3ğ‘ƒğ¹3.2superscript103italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(F)=3.2\times 10^{-3}) while marginal improvements are found for NGC 507 (Pâ¢(F)=2.7Ã—10-2ğ‘ƒğ¹2.7superscript102italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.7 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(F)=2.7\times 10^{-2}) and NGC 5846 (Pâ¢(F)=7.6Ã—10-2ğ‘ƒğ¹7.6superscript102italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:7.6 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(F)=7.6\times 10^{-2}). Although only NGC 4472, 5044, and 5846 are indicated to have formally unacceptable fits in terms of the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} null hypothesis probability for models with or without the edge, the fact that adding the edge lowers Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} by much more than 1 (i.e., Pâ¢(F)â‰ª1much-less-thanğ‘ƒğ¹1italic-P OPEN:( italic-F CLOSE:) RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1P(F)\ll 1) in several cases indicates that the fits are indeed better with the edge in those systems.

For every system where we found NH<NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}<\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} for the standard absorber (Â§3.1), we find that NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ systematically increases when the oxygen edge is added. Although the addition of the edge results in NHâˆ¼NHGalsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\sim\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} for many of these systems we find that in some cases (most notably NGC 5044) NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ is still significantly less than NHGalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}, and the fits in the central bin, though improved, are still formally unacceptable. Thus, adding the edge does significantly improve the models, but it apparently is not the only improvement required in some cases. We discuss another mechanism to improve the fits below in Â§3.6.3.

We obtain the best constraints on the edge optical depth for NGC 507, 1399, 4472, 4649, and 5044. Only for these systems is Ï„>0ğœ0italic-tau RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0\tau>0 significant at the 95% confidence level in the central bin whether or not NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ is fixed to the Galactic value for the standard absorber model. In some cases Ï„>0ğœ0italic-tau RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0\tau>0 is significant at the 99% level â€“ we discuss individual cases below in Â§3.5.

We have also investigated whether these oxygen absorption profiles can be reproduced by a profile of decreasing oxygen abundance; i.e., the strong KÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha lines of O vii and O viii lie between 0.5-0.65 keV. If instead we allow the oxygen abundance in the hot gas to be a free parameter in the fits we find that typically the best-fitting oxygen abundance is zero, and the quality of most of the fits are improved similarly to that found when the oxygen edge is added. This degeneracy is not surprising owing to the limited energy resolution of the PSPC. The notable exception is NGC 1399 where the fits for r=1â¢â€²ğ‘Ÿ1â€²italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²r=1\arcmin are only improved to Ï‡2=95.9superscriptğœ’295.9italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:95.9\chi^{2}=95.9 for zero oxygen abundance as opposed to 83.7 for the edge (both have variable NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}). However, zero oxygen abundance in the centers is highly unlikely because of the expected enrichment from the stars in the central galaxy. And if instead we consider plausible O/Fe ratios to be at least 1/2 solar in NGC 507, 1399, 4472, 4649, and 5044, then the fits are not as much improved as when adding the edge.

As mentioned above (and in PAPER1) we find that for most radii the constraints on the edge energy are not very precise which is why we fixed the edge energy in our analysis. The best constraints are available for NGC 1399 and 5044 within the central bin for which we obtain 0.51-0.05+0.05subscriptsuperscript0.510.050.05NUMBER:0.51 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.51^{+0.05}_{-0.05} keV and 0.51-0.05+0.09subscriptsuperscript0.510.090.05NUMBER:0.51 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.09 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.51^{+0.09}_{-0.05} keV (90% confidence) for the edge energies for the standard absorber models with variable NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}. (Models with fixed foreground Galactic columns give similar results; e.g., 0.53-0.03+0.05subscriptsuperscript0.530.050.03NUMBER:0.53 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.03 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0.53^{+0.05}_{-0.03} keV for NGC 1399.)

These constraints are consistent with the lower ionization states of oxygen but not edges from the highest states Oâ€‰vi-viii. Due to the limited resolution we can add additional edges to â€œshareâ€ the Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau obtained for the Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edges, although when using a two-edge model a significant Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau cannot be obtained for edge energies above âˆ¼0.65similar-toabsent0.65RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.65\sim 0.65 keV corresponding to âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\simOâ€‰vi.

We elaborate further on the results for individual systems. When comparing NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ profiles to those obtained from previous ROSAT PSPC studies we implicitly account for any differences in the plasma codes and solar abundances used.

In Figure 1 we display the results for the three systems where the spectral parameters are well determined in seven annuli. These observations thus generally correspond to the highest S/N data in our sample. The evidence for intrinsic oxygen absorption is strongest for these systems.

NGC 507: The oxygen edge optical depth, Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R), falls gradually from the center and remains significantly non-zero out to Râˆ¼4â¢â€²similar-toğ‘…4â€²italic-R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4 â€²R\sim 4\arcmin; e.g., in the R=3â¢â€²ğ‘…3â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 â€²R=3\arcmin-4.25â¢â€²4.25â€²NUMBER:4.25 â€²4.25\arcmin annulus the 95% confidence lower limits on Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau are 0.39 and 0.24 respectively in models with fixed (Galactic) and variable NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ for the standard absorber. The values of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ for the standard absorber are consistent with those obtained by Kim & Fabbiano (1995) with the PSPC data.

NGC 1399: This system exhibits the most centrally peaked Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau profile in our sample. Within the central arcminute Ï„>0.26ğœ0.26italic-tau RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0.26\tau>0.26 and 0.33 at 99% confidence respectively for the fixed and free NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ models. At larger radii the non-zero optical depths are also quite significant; e.g., for R=2.5â¢â€²ğ‘…2.5â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5 â€²R=2.5\arcmin-4â¢â€²4â€²NUMBER:4 â€²4\arcmin Ï„>0.64ğœ0.64italic-tau RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0.64\tau>0.64 and 0.50 at 99% confidence for the fixed and free NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ models. We obtain values of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ for the standard absorber consistent with the previous PSPC study by Jones et al (1997).

NGC 5044: The second radial bin (R=1â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²R=1\arcmin-2â¢â€²2â€²NUMBER:2 â€²2\arcmin) actually has a smaller uncertainty on the oxygen edge optical depth than the central bin; i.e., the 95% lower limits on Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau are 0.87 and 0.79 respectively for the fixed and free NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ models. In fact, the corresponding 99% lower limits are 0.75 and 0.42 for R=1â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²R=1\arcmin-2â¢â€²2â€²NUMBER:2 â€²2\arcmin which are larger than the values for the R=1â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²R=1\arcmin bin. The optical depth remains significantly non-zero out to the R=3â¢â€²ğ‘…3â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 â€²R=3\arcmin-4.5â¢â€²4.5â€²NUMBER:4.5 â€²4.5\arcmin bin in which we obtain 95% lower limits on Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau of 0.36 and 0.10 for the fixed and free NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ models. Our values of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ are consistent with those obtained from the PSPC data by David et al (1994).
In Figure 2 we display the results for the three systems where the spectral parameters are well determined in 5-6 annuli. Only for NGC 4472 is the intrinsic oxygen absorption clearly significant.

NGC 2563: The uncertainties on Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R) are large and consistent with zero at the center. However, the shapes of the error regions, especially the large uncertainty at the center, are consistent with the same type of increasing Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau profile with decreasing Rğ‘…italic-RR found for the systems with seven annuli.

NGC 4472: The optical depth is consistent with Ï„âˆ¼2similar-toğœ2italic-tau RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2\tau\sim 2 for Râ‰²5â¢â€²less-than-or-similar-toğ‘…5â€²italic-R RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:5 â€²R\lesssim 5\arcmin and then decreases rapidly at larger radii. Unlike the other systems with evidence for intrinsic absorption Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau is most significant away from the central bin; i.e., for R=3.25â¢â€²ğ‘…3.25â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.25 â€²R=3.25\arcmin-5â¢â€²5â€²NUMBER:5 â€²5\arcmin the 95% confidence lower limits on Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau are 1.62 and 1.75 respectively for the fixed and free NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ models. (The corresponding 99% lower limits are 1.27 and 1.46.) Interestingly, Râˆ¼5â¢â€²similar-toğ‘…5â€²italic-R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:5 â€²R\sim 5\arcmin corresponds to the region where Irwin & Sarazin (1996) identified holes in the X-ray emission from visual examination of the PSPC image, and thus the large oxygen edge optical depths could be related to these holes. The sub-Galactic columns obtained for the standard absorber with variable NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ are consistent with those obtained by Forman et al (1993).

NGC 5846: The uncertainties on Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R) are large, and although a substantial amount of intrinsic absorption is allowed by the data, no excess absorption is required.

In Figure 3 we display the results for the three systems where the spectral parameters are well determined in 4 annuli. The uncertainties on Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R) are large for each of these systems and thus no intrinsic oxygen absorption is clearly required by the data.

In Figure 4 we display the results for the one system where the spectral parameters are well determined in only 3 annuli, NGC 4649. In contrast to the systems with 4 annuli we find evidence for significant intrinsic oxygen absorption in the central bin for NGC 4649.

NGC 4649: In the central radial bin the 90% lower limits on Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau are 0.55 and 0.20 respectively for for the fixed and free NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ models, although only the 95% lower limit for the model with fixed NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ is significantly larger than zero (Table 1). Our values of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ for the standard absorber are consistent with those obtained from the PSPC data by Trinchieri et al (1997).

In the inhomogeneous cooling flow scenario the hot gas is expected to emit over a continuous range of temperatures in regions where the cooling time is less than the age of the system. We consider a simple model of a cooling flow where the hot gas cools at constant pressure from some upper temperature, Tmaxsubscriptğ‘‡maxitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm max} (e.g., Johnstone et al 1992). The differential emission measure of the cooling gas is proportional to MË™/Î›â¢(T)Ë™ğ‘€Î›ğ‘‡OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end MULOP:divide Lambda OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\dot{M}/\Lambda(T), where MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M} is the mass deposition rate of gas cooling out of the flow, and Î›â¢(T)Î›ğ‘‡Lambda OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\Lambda(T) is the cooling function of the gas (in our case, the MEKAL plasma code).

Since the gas is assumed to be cooling from some upper temperature Tmaxsubscriptğ‘‡maxitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm max}, the cooling flow model requires that there be a reservoir of hot gas emitting at temperature Tmaxsubscriptğ‘‡maxitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm max} but is not cooling out of the flow. Consequently, our cooling flow model actually consists of two components, CF+1T, where â€œCFâ€ is the emission from the cooling gas and â€œ1Tâ€ is emission from the hot ambient gas. We set Tmaxsubscriptğ‘‡maxitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm max} of the CF component equal to the temperature of the 1T component, and both components are modified by the same photoelectric absorption. This simple model of a cooling flow is appropriate for the low energy resolution of the ROSAT PSPC and has the advantage of being well studied, relatively easy to compute, and a good fit to the ASCA data of many elliptical galaxies and groups (e.g., Buote & Fabian 1998; Buote 1999, 2000a).

When fitting this cooling flow model to the ROSAT spectra of the galaxies and groups in our sample we find that if only absorption from the standard cold absorber model with solar abundances is included then we obtain results identical to the single-phase models; i.e., the CF component is clearly suppressed by the fits. Since the CF model includes temperature components below âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV it has stronger O vii and O viii lines than the single-phase models which, as shown above, already predict too much emission from these lines. It is thus not surprising that only when an intrinsic oxygen absorption edge is included in the fits can we obtain a significant contribution from a CF component.

Even when adding the oxygen edge the cooling flow models do not improve the fits perceptively in any case. And since the magnitude of Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau for the oxygen edge is degenerate with MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M} of the cooling flow component, the constraints on both parameters are quite uncertain. For NGC 5044, which has the best constraints, adding the CF component improves Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} from 156.5 to 154.1 for 116 dof within the central arcminute (i.e., marginal improvement). The oxygen edge optical depths are consistent with those obtained from the single-phase analysis. Only within r=2â¢â€²ğ‘Ÿ2â€²italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 â€²r=2\arcmin is there an indication of significant cooling with MË™âˆ¼12â¢Mâ˜‰â¢yr-1similar-toË™ğ‘€12subscriptğ‘€â˜‰superscriptyr1OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:12 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ POSTSUBSCRIPT:end yr POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$\dot{M}$}}\sim 12\hbox{{$M_{\sun}$}}\rm yr^{-1} which is very consistent with the ROSAT results of David et al (1994) within the same radius. (Our mass deposition rates have large statistical uncertainties because of the inclusion of the intrinsic oxygen edge.)
Thus, simple cooling flow models give results that are entirely consistent with the single-phase models.

A two-temperature model (2T) is a more flexible multiphase emission model than the constant-pressure cooling flow and can very accurately mimic a cooling flow spectrum over typical X-ray energies (Buote, Canizares, & Fabian 1999). If we restrict the temperatures of the 2T model to lie between âˆ¼0.5-2similar-toabsent0.52RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2\sim 0.5-2 keV appropriate for hot gas near the virial temperatures of these galaxies and groups, then we obtain results equivalent to the cooling flow models above; e.g., (1) the extra temperature component is only allowed if the intrinsic oxygen edge included, and (2) results are entirely consistent with the single-phase models. Since the temperatures of the 2T models are fitted separately, constraints on the 2T models are even poorer than the cooling flows because of the extra free parameter.

section.h4: 3.6.3 Two-Phase Medium: Warm and Hot Gas

div.p: Recall that when fitted with only a standard absorber with solar abundances that NHâ¢(R)subscriptğ‘Hğ‘…italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}(R) decreases as Rğ‘…italic-RR decreases such that NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ is less then NHGalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}â€‰ near R=0ğ‘…0italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:0R=0 for most of the galaxies and groups (Â§3.1). This trend implies the existence of excess soft X-ray emission above that produced by the hot gas, the signature of which is most evident at the centers of these galaxies and groups. Although the sub-Galactic values of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ are only marginally significant in many cases, they are highly significant for NGC 4472 and NGC 5044.

If the excess soft X-rays near the centers represent emission from coronal gas, then the temperatures must be â‰²0.1less-than-or-similar-toabsent0.1RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.1\lesssim 0.1 keV (i.e., distinctly cooler than the hot gas phase). For NGC 5044, which has the most significant sub-Galactic column densities in the central bins, we find that when adding an extra temperature component to the single-phase model modified only by the standard absorber with NH=NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}=\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} (i.e., no intrinsic oxygen edge), that the fits are improved very similarly to the single-phase models when NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ is allowed to take a value significantly less than NHGalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}. For example, in the central bin the fit improves from Ï‡2=191superscriptğœ’2191italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:191\chi^{2}=191 (118 dof) for the 1T model to Ï‡2=133superscriptğœ’2133italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:133\chi^{2}=133 (116 dof) for the 2T model (both models with NH=NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}=\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}}) very similar to the result obtained for the 1T model with NH<NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}<\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} (i.e., Ï‡2=139superscriptğœ’2139italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:139\chi^{2}=139 for 117 dof â€“ â€œFreeâ€ in Table 1). Essentially the same large improvement is found for the second radial bin (R=1â¢â€²-2â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²2â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€² ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 â€²R=1\arcmin-2\arcmin). Significant but smaller improvement in the fits (Î”â¢Ï‡2âˆ¼10similar-toÎ”superscriptğœ’210Delta italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\Delta\chi^{2}\sim 10) is also seen in in the third and fourth bins (i.e. R=2â¢â€²-4.5â¢â€²ğ‘…2â€²4.5â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 â€² ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4.5 â€²R=2\arcmin-4.5\arcmin).

The inferred temperature of the soft component in the central bin is T=0.05-0.03+0.03ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscript0.050.030.03italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.03 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.03 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.05^{+0.03}_{-0.03} keV (6-4+4Ã—105subscriptsuperscript644superscript105NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end6^{+4}_{-4}\times 10^{5} K) at 90% confidence consistent with values obtained for other radii; i.e., consistent with â€œwarmâ€ gas rather than â€œhotâ€ gas near the virial temperatures of the galaxies and groups. Gas at these warm temperatures is not optically thin to photons with energies near 0.5 keV (e.g., Krolik & Kallman 1984), and thus this warm gas may be responsible for the intrinsic oxygen absorption inferred in Â§3.4. However, since this warm gas is apparently partially photoionized by the hot gas (and perhaps by itself) a proper calculation of the emission from the warm gas must consider radiative transfer effects which is beyond the scope of this paper. (We shall continue to use the optically thin models in this paper.) We discuss the properties of this warm gas in more detail in Â§5.

The improvement obtained in the fit when adding a component of warm gas to the single-phase model (NH=NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}=\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}}) is somewhat larger than that obtained when adding the single oxygen edge (i.e., Ï‡2=133superscriptğœ’2133italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:133\chi^{2}=133 for 116 dof for the 2T model versus Ï‡2=156.5superscriptğœ’2156.5italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:156.5\chi^{2}=156.5 for 117 dof for the edge â€“ Table 1). Unfortunately, due to the limited energy resolution of the PSPC it is very difficult to obtain simultaneous constraints on both absorption and emission models for both the warm and hot gas.

The most reliable constraints on the warm gas component are possible for NGC 5044 because for 1T models we find that NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ of the standard absorber is well below NHGalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}â€‰ at small Rğ‘…italic-RR whether or not an intrinsic oxygen edge is included (Figure 1). For a 2T model with an intrinsic oxygen edge we find that the temperature of the warm component in the central bin is T=0.06-0.04+0.03ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscript0.060.030.04italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.06 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.03 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.04 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.06^{+0.03}_{-0.04} keV (7-5+4Ã—105subscriptsuperscript745superscript105NUMBER:7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end7^{+4}_{-5}\times 10^{5} K) at 90% confidence consistent with that obtained for the 2T model without the oxygen edge. The oxygen edge optical depth is not very well constrained, Ï„=0.8-0.6+0.4,1.2-0.7+0.8ğœsubscriptsuperscript0.80.40.6subscriptsuperscript1.20.80.7italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:1.2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.7 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau=0.8^{+0.4}_{-0.6},1.2^{+0.8}_{-0.7} (90% confidence) in the inner two bins respectively, which is about half the best-fitting value and near the 95% lower limit of Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau obtained without including the emission from the warm gas (Table 1). The weakened constraint on the oxygen edge optical depth for the 2T model of NGC 5044 reflects the relatively small improvement in the fit (Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} of 127 for 115 dof) over the 2T model without an edge. For the other galaxies, most notably NGC 1399, the constraints on the oxygen edge are not weakened nearly as much.

Emission from such a warm gas component is consistent with, though not as clearly required by, the PSPC data for the other systems. Only for NGC 4472 is clearly significant improvement found when adding both the warm gas component and the oxygen edge. Temperatures (Tâˆ¼(5-10)Ã—105similar-toğ‘‡510superscript105italic-T RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10 CLOSE:) MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim(5-10)\times 10^{5} K) and the reduction in edge optical depth are obtained similarly as found for NGC 5044. Future observations with better energy resolution are required to definitively confirm and measure the emission and absorption properties of the warm gas in all of these systems.

(i) Calibration: The gain of the PSPC is well calibrated and in particular no significant calibration problems near 0.5 keV have been reported.222See http://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/rosat. The large values of Ï„âˆ¼1similar-toğœ1italic-tau RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\tau\sim 1 obtained in the central regions imply that the absorption significantly affects a large energy range comparable to the energy resolution of the PSPC; e.g., the Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edge absorbs 25% of the flux at 0.8 keV for Ï„=1ğœ1italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\tau=1; i.e. possible residual calibration errors near 0.5 keV where the effective area is changing rapidly (e.g., Figure 1 of Snowden et al 1994) can not explain the need for absorption at higher energies. Moreover, the shape of Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R) is not the same for each system as would be expected if calibration were responsible for the intrinsic oxygen absorption found in half of the sample; e.g., Ï„â¢(R)ğœğ‘…italic-tau OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\tau(R) for NGC 1399 is much more centrally peaked than for NGC 4472 or the other systems. The agreement between the absorption inferred by the PSPC and ASCA mentioned below in Â§4 further argues against a systematic error intrinsic to the PSPC being responsible for the measured oxygen absorption.

(ii) Galactic Columns: All of the objects in our sample reside at high Galactic latitude, and thus the Galactic absorption should be fairly uniform over the relevant 5â¢â€²5â€²NUMBER:5 â€²5\arcmin-10â¢â€²10â€²NUMBER:10 â€²10\arcmin scales. Errors in the assumed Galactic columns (Dickey & Lockman, 1990) should only affect the baseline value and not the variation with radius.

(iii) Background: Errors in the background level affect most seriously the lowest energies (â‰²0.4less-than-or-similar-toabsent0.4RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.4\lesssim 0.4 keV) which are also most sensitive to the column density of the standard absorber model. Hence, measurements of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ at the largest radii (which have lowest S/N) are the most affected by background errors. The hydrogen column densities measured in the outer radii (see Figures 1-4) are very similar to and are usually consistent with the assumed Galactic values within the estimated 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma errors which attests to the accuracy of our background estimates. The intrinsic oxygen optical depths in the central radial bins are very insensitive to the background level.

The intrinsic oxygen absorption indicated by the PSPC data in half of our sample is most significant within the central 1â¢â€²-2â¢â€²1â€²2â€²NUMBER:1 â€² ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 â€²1\arcmin-2\arcmin which is similar to the width of the ASCA PSF. In addition, since the ASCA SIS is limited to E>0.5ğ¸0.5italic-E RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0.5E>0.5 keV, and the efficiency near 0.5 keV is severely limited due to instrumental oxygen absorption, it cannot be expected that ASCA can distinguish an oxygen edge from a standard absorber with solar abundances. However, it is instructive to examine the consistency between results obtained from spatially resolved (PSPC) and single-aperture (ASCA ) methods. As mentioned in PAPER1 the results obtained when adding an oxygen edge to the ASCA data of NGC 1399 and 5044 are consistent with those obtained with the PSPC. Since similar results are found for other objects in our sample showing intrinsic absorption, we focus on NGC 1399 for illustration.

Previously we (Buote, 1999) have fitted two-temperature models to the accumulated ASCA SIS and GIS data within Râ‰ˆ5â¢â€²ğ‘…5â€²italic-R RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5 â€²R\approx 5\arcmin of NGC 1399 and obtained NHc=49-9+6Ã—1020superscriptsubscriptğ‘Hcsuperscriptsubscript4996superscript1020italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:49 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:9 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm c}=49_{-9}^{+6}\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} (90% confidence) for the standard absorber on the cooler temperature component. Using the meteoritic solar abundances (see Â§4.1.3 of PAPER2) slightly modifies this result to NHc=40-7+6Ã—1020superscriptsubscriptğ‘Hcsuperscriptsubscript4076superscript1020italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40 POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:7 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm c}=40_{-7}^{+6}\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} which is about 30 times larger than the Galactic value (NHc=1.3Ã—1020superscriptsubscriptğ‘Hc1.3superscript1020italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}^{\rm c}=1.3\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}). Comparing this result to those obtained from the PSPC for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 keV (Fig 1) we see that the ASCA column density is qualitatively similar to the value of NHâ‰ˆ20Ã—1020subscriptğ‘H20superscript1020italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:20 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}\approx 20\times 10^{20} obtained within R=1â¢â€²ğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€²R=1\arcmin and is consistent with the total column within Râ‰ˆ5â¢â€²ğ‘…5â€²italic-R RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5 â€²R\approx 5\arcmin. If instead the columns of the standard absorber are fixed to Galactic on both components, and an intrinsic Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edge is added to the cooler component, then we obtain Ï„=6.0-0.7+0.7ğœsubscriptsuperscript6.00.70.7italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:6.0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.7 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau=6.0^{+0.7}_{-0.7} (90% confidence) for the ASCA data. Again this ASCA result is similar to Ï„âˆ¼4similar-toğœ4italic-tau RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4\tau\sim 4 in the central PSPC bin and is very consistent with the value of Ï„=5.7ğœ5.7italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:5.7\tau=5.7 obtained from adding up the best-fitting values obtained with the PSPC within R=5â¢â€²ğ‘…5â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 â€²R=5\arcmin. Therefore, the oxygen edge provides as good or better description of the excess absorption inferred from multitemperature models of ASCA data within the central few arcminutes as a standard cold absorber with solar abundances, and yields optical depths that are consistent with those obtained with the PSPC data.

Although a similar consistency is achieved for NGC 4472 the interpretation of the absorption of the two-component model of the single-aperture ASCA data is not so straightforward because the absorption is not obviously concentrated at the center (i.e. on the cooler temperature component). In fact, a spatially uniform absorber within R=5â¢â€²ğ‘…5â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 â€²R=5\arcmin is probably a better description of the PSPC data. If the column densities on both temperature components are tied together for the two-temperature model of the ASCA data the quality of the fit is slightly worse (Î”â¢Ï‡2=8Î”superscriptğœ’28Delta italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:8\Delta\chi^{2}=8 for 361 dof), but NHâ‰ˆ11Ã—1020subscriptğ‘H11superscript1020italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:11 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}\approx 11\times 10^{20} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} which is a fair representation of the average NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ profile obtained from the PSPC for Emin=0.5subscriptğ¸min0.5italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5E_{\rm min}=0.5 keV (Fig 2). Similar agreement is found for the Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edge when applied to both temperature components.

section.h2: 5 Warm Ionized Gas in Cooling Flows

div.p: We consider now in some detail the properties of the intrinsic absorber and their implications. Initially we focus our attention on the physical state of the absorber.

Models of dust grains indicate that dust can give rise to significant amounts of absorption between 0.1-1 keV (e.g., Laor & Draine 1993). In principle such grains could explain the intrinsic absorption we have inferred for energies above âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV in the PSPC data of half of the galaxies and groups in our study as well as the excess absorption detected for energies above âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV in the ASCA data of bright galaxies, groups, and clusters.

However, dust should also heavily absorb X-rays with energies between 0.1-0.40.10.4NUMBER:0.1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.40.1-0.4 keV (e.g., Laor & Draine 1993) which is inconsistent with the ROSAT data for the 10 galaxies and groups in our study and, e.g., the large sample of ROSAT clusters studied by Allen & Fabian (1997). To evade this constraint (i.e., no absorption below 0.4 keV) an unconventional model for the formation of dust grains has to be postulated; e.g., dust grains condense out of a medium in which helium remains ionized (Arnaud & Mushotzky, 1998). Even if we consider the (rather unlikely) possibility that dust does not absorb X-rays below âˆ¼0.4similar-toabsent0.4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4\sim 0.4 keV, we still have that dust cannot account for the excess X-ray emission at those energies implied by the sub-Galactic column densities (Â§3.1 and 3.6.3).

Other strong arguments against the existence of large quantities of oxygen-absorbing dust in cooling flows have been made in the past. At the centers of cooling flows where the gas density is largest and the soft X-ray absorption is most significant dust should not be present in large quantities because the grains are rapidly destroyed by sputtering by the hot gas (e.g., Tsai & Mathews 1995; Voit & Donahue 1995). A different argument due to Voit & Donahue (1995) considers that the transient heating of the grains by X-rays from the hot gas prevents CO from fully condensing onto dust grains. Consequently, significant amounts of oxygen would remain in molecular gas which would produce CO emission from rotational lines that are inconsistent with the generally negligible CO detections in cooling flows (e.g., Bregman, Hogg, & Roberts 1992; Oâ€™Dea et al 1994).

section.h3: 5.2 Temperature of the Warm Ionized Gas

div.p: Unlike dust all of the key features of the observed soft X-ray absorption and emission can be accounted for if the absorber is (primarily) collisionally ionized gas. The lack of intrinsic absorption observed for energies between âˆ¼0.2-0.4similar-toabsent0.20.4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.4\sim 0.2-0.4 keV in the ROSAT data requires that H and He be completely ionized implying a gas temperature Tâ‰³1.0Ã—105greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘‡1.0superscript105italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:1.0 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\gtrsim 1.0\times 10^{5} K (e.g., Sutherland & Dopita 1993). In order to have significant absorption at 0.5 keV the temperature cannot be larger than â‰ˆ1Ã—106absent1superscript106RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\approx 1\times 10^{6} K (see Figure 2 of Krolik & Kallman 1984). This absorbing temperature range (T=105-6ğ‘‡superscript1056italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT=10^{5-6} K) is entirely consistent with that inferred from the gas emission to explain the sub-Galactic column densities especially for NGC 5044 (Â§3.6.3). This consistency of absorption and emission properties lends strong support to the idea that the absorber is warm ionized gas.

At these temperatures carbon and nitrogen are not completely ionized (e.g., Nahar & Pradhan 1997; Sutherland & Dopita 1993), and thus these elements will also contribute to the soft X-ray absorption. For nitrogen the states Nâ€‰iv-vi are significant, and their edge energies span 0.46-0.55 keV (rest frame) which are consistent with the edge energy range determined from the PSPC data. Since N/O=1/8.51NO18.51N MULOP:divide O RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:8.51\rm N/O=1/8.51 (assuming solar abundance ratios), and the threshold cross sections for absorption are similar for N and O, only âˆ¼12%similar-toabsentpercent12RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:12 POSTFIX:percent\sim 12\% of the optical depth we have measured in each system likely arises from ionized nitrogen.

The ionization fraction for carbon changes rapidly near T=105ğ‘‡superscript105italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT=10^{5} K with Câ€‰vâ€‰ dominating for temperatures above this value and up to Tâ‰ˆ106ğ‘‡superscript106italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 10^{6} K. The edge energy for Câ€‰vâ€‰ is 0.39 keV, and since C/Oâ‰ˆ0.5CO0.5C MULOP:divide O RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.5\rm C/O\approx 0.5 (assuming solar abundance ratios) and the threshold cross sections of C and O are similar, the optical depth of Câ€‰vâ€‰ is about half that expected from a dominant ionized state of oxygen. However, the strong instrumental carbon absorption leaves the PSPC with essentially no effective area over energies 0.28 keV to âˆ¼0.4similar-toabsent0.4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4\sim 0.4 keV (e.g., see Figure 1 of Snowden et al 1994), and thus it is only possible to detect intrinsic absorption from the Câ€‰vâ€‰ edge for energies above âˆ¼0.4similar-toabsent0.4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4\sim 0.4 keV even considering the smearing due to the limited energy resolution. This is entirely consistent with the variation of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ with Eminsubscriptğ¸minitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{\rm min} described in Â§3.3.

Considering the energy resolution and effective area curve of the PSPC, the 0.532 keV edge that we have used to parameterize the intrinsic absorption is likely an average of the âˆ¼40%similar-toabsentpercent40RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:40 POSTFIX:percent\sim 40\% contribution from the Câ€‰vâ€‰ edge (0.39 keV) and Nâ€‰iv-vi edges (0.46-0.55 keV) with a âˆ¼60%similar-toabsentpercent60RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:60 POSTFIX:percent\sim 60\% contribution from ionized oxygen states. Although as discussed in Â§3.4 the PSPC data cannot distinguish between multi-edge models, when using a more realistic absorber model consisting of Câ€‰vâ€‰ and Nâ€‰viâ€‰ and an oxygen edge, we are able to obtain a significant optical depth for the oxygen edge for energies as high as âˆ¼0.75similar-toabsent0.75RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.75\sim 0.75 keV consistent with Oâ€‰viiâ€‰ (0.74 keV). However, to insure that oxygen produces at least as much absorption as the C and N edges, the PSPC data also require a contribution from edges around âˆ¼0.6-0.65similar-toabsent0.60.65RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.6 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.65\sim 0.6-0.65 keV corresponding to edges from Oâ€‰iv-vi.

Consideration of these maximum allowed ionization states for oxygen indicates that the maximum temperature of the warm gas is more like Tâ‰ˆ5Ã—105ğ‘‡5superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 5\times 10^{5} K if the gas is isothermal and collisionally ionized (e.g., Nahar 1999; Sutherland & Dopita 1993). The absorption signature of this warm gas is not one dominant feature near 0.5 keV but is rather a relatively broad trough over energies 0.4 to âˆ¼0.8similar-toabsent0.8RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.8\sim 0.8 keV for total optical depths of unity (see Figure 1 of Krolik & Kallman 1984).

(We mention that the edge energies we have quoted are from Daltabuit & Cox (1972) though Gould & Jung (1991) argue that the edge energy for Oâ€‰iâ€‰ is âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10 eV higher. Such differences may be relevant for modeling future high resolution spectra but are unimportant for our present discussion with the PSPC data.)

Hence, a proper absorber model needs to consider several edges from different ionization states of oxygen as well as edges from ions of C and N. Since the warm gas absorbs photons from the hot gas the assumption of collisional ionization equilibrium is also not strictly valid nor is it clear that the warm gas is fully optically thin to its own radiation as was assumed in Â§3.6.3 for convenience. Consequently, the single-edge oxygen absorber that we have used throughout this paper (and PAPER1) has been intended primarily as a phenomenological tool to establish the existence and to study the gross properties of the absorber which is appropriate for the low spectral resolution afforded by the PSPC data. If our basic results are confirmed with the substantially higher quality data from Chandra and XMM , then it will be appropriate to expend the effort to construct rigorous models of the warm absorber accounting for many edges and possible radiative transfer effects that are not currently available in xspec .
