The quoted errors on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ refer to 95% confidence limits on Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau (â€œFixâ€ in Table 1) and assume solar abundances. The accumulation timescale, tacc=Mabs/MË™subscriptğ‘¡accsubscriptğ‘€absË™ğ‘€italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start acc POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\hbox{{$t_{\rm acc}$}}=\hbox{{$M_{\rm abs}$}}/\hbox{{$\dot{M}$}}, reflects both the 95% uncertainties on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ and the 90% errors on MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M}. The mass of hot gas, Mhotsubscriptğ‘€hotitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start hot POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm hot}, and the 95% errors computed within the 3D radius are also given. These values of Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ probably are over-estimates (see beginning of Â§5.3).

div.p: As suggested in PAPER1 this warm ionized absorber might be the gas that has dropped out of the putative cooling flow during the lifetime of the galaxy or group and thus could provide the confirmation of the inhomogeneous cooling flow scenario that has been suggested to operate in massive elliptical galaxies, groups, and clusters (e.g., Fabian 1994). To make this connection between our measurements of oxygen absorption and the cooling flow scenario we first estimate the mass of absorbing material implied by the measured optical depths. This mass is then compared to the cooling flow mass deposition rate inferred from ASCA data.

Before computing the absorber masses some caveats must be discussed. First, although the simple constant-pressure cooling flow model discussed in Â§3.6.1 can describe the X-ray emission of the hot gas just as well as the single-phase model, it does not describe the excess 0.2-0.4 keV X-rays presumably arising from the emission of the warm absorbing gas (Â§3.6.3). Although at this time we cannot exclude the possibility that with a more rigorous treatment of the absorption and emission properties of the warm gas (see end of previous section) that the simple cooling flow model could be compatible with the PSPC data between 0.2-0.4 keV, it is quite possible that an important modification of the simple cooling flow model is required (see Â§5.5). As a convenient benchmark for comparison to most previous studies we shall consider here the mass deposition rates predicted by the constant-pressure cooling flow models.

Second, the oxygen edge optical depths predicted by the single-edge models without including the emission from the warm gas certainly are overestimates. Recall that when including the warm gas emission in NGC 5044 that Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau reduces to a value near the 95% lower limit of the result obtained without including the warm gas emission (Â§3.6.3). Of equal importance, when including additional edges the inferred optical depth for each edge decreases, and we expect several edges from different ionization states of oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen to contribute (Â§5.2). Since the absorption of an edge is not linear in the energy of the edge (i.e., A0â¢(E)=expâ¡[-Ï„0â¢(E/E0)-3]subscriptğ´0ğ¸subscriptğœ0superscriptğ¸subscriptğ¸03italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E MULOP:divide italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]A_{0}(E)=\exp[-\tau_{0}(E/E_{0})^{-3}] and A1â¢(E)â¢A2â¢(E)â‰ A1+2â¢(E)subscriptğ´1ğ¸subscriptğ´2ğ¸subscriptğ´12ğ¸italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:) italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:)A_{1}(E)A_{2}(E)\neq A_{1+2}(E) if the edge energies E1â‰ E2subscriptğ¸1subscriptğ¸2italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:not-equals italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{1}\neq E_{2}), by spreading multiple edges over a large energy range one can produce the observed absorption with smaller total optical depth than can be achieved with a single edge. Consequently, the single-edge optical depths obtained in Â§3.4 should be considered upper limits.

Let us now estimate the amount of absorbing material implied by these absorption measurements with these caveats in mind, and in particular with the assumption that the inferred absorber masses are most likely over-estimates. Assuming the optical depths refer to the Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edge, then the measured values of Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau imply a hydrogen column density (assuming Ïƒ=5.5Ã—10-19ğœ5.5superscript1019italic-sigma RELOP:equals NUMBER:5.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sigma=5.5\times 10^{-19} cm22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} at threshold) and thus a mass within a projected radius, Rğ‘…italic-RR,

div.p: where Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau is the optical depth of the Oâ€‰iâ€‰ edge and O/H is the oxygen abundance of the absorber. Although the projected mass is larger than the mass within the 3D radius r=Rğ‘Ÿğ‘…italic-r RELOP:equals italic-Rr=R, the value of Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau in equation (1) slightly underestimates the 3D value as discussed in (Â§3.2); i.e. these projection effects approximately cancel. The metallicity of the hot gas in the central bins for the objects in our sample are larger than solar (PAPER2), and thus we expect the same for the absorber. Since the oxygen abundance is uncertain we shall quote results assuming O is solar and recognize that Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ could be overestimated by a factor of 2-3 in the central bin. The expected contribution from carbon and nitrogen (Â§5) to Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau also reduces Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ by another âˆ¼40%similar-toabsentpercent40RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:40 POSTFIX:percent\sim 40\%.

In Table 2 we give Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ for NGC 507, 1399, 4472, 4649, and 5044 in both the central bin (R=1â¢â€²)ğ‘…1â€²OPEN:( italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€² CLOSE:)(R=1\arcmin) and the total mass interior to the largest bin investigated; the edge optical depths used refer to the single-phase models since the cooling flow models give entirely consistent values (Â§3.6.1). The mass deposition rates, MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M}, listed in the second column are determined from the accumulated ASCA data within radii of râˆ¼3â¢â€²-5â¢â€²similar-toğ‘Ÿ3â€²5â€²italic-r RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3 â€² ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 â€²r\sim 3\arcmin-5\arcmin. (The ASCA spectra place much tighter constraints on the total MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M}â€‰ than do the ROSAT spectral data.) The results for NGC 1399, 4472, and 5044 are taken from Buote (1999). For NGC 507 and 4649 we re-analyzed the data sets as prepared in Buote & Fabian (1998) and fitted cooling flow models analogously to that done in Buote (1999). That is, the spectra were fitted with (1) a constant pressure cooling flow component, (2) an isothermal component representing the ambient gas, and (3) for NGC 4649 an extra high-temperature bremsstrahlung component. Since the cooling flow model assumes constant pressure and neglects the gravitational work done on the cooling gas, the value of MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M}â€‰ is an upper limit. This over-estimate is typically â‰²30%less-than-or-similar-toabsentpercent30RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:30 POSTFIX:percent\lesssim 30\% (e.g., the agreement of different cooling flow models in Allen et al 2000b).

Let us focus on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ and the accumulation time, tacc=Mabs/MË™subscriptğ‘¡accsubscriptğ‘€absË™ğ‘€italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start acc POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\hbox{{$t_{\rm acc}$}}=\hbox{{$M_{\rm abs}$}}/\hbox{{$\dot{M}$}}, within the central bin (R=1â¢â€²)ğ‘…1â€²OPEN:( italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 â€² CLOSE:)(R=1\arcmin) where the measured optical depths are most significant and the fits are most clearly improved when the edge is added; i.e. we consider the results for the central bin to be most reliable. Assuming an age of the universe, tage=1.3Ã—1010subscriptğ‘¡age1.3superscript1010italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start age POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$t_{\rm age}$}}=1.3\times 10^{10}yr, examination of Table 2 reveals that within the central bin taccâˆ¼(0.1-0.5)â¢tagesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘¡acc0.10.5subscriptğ‘¡ageitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start acc POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( NUMBER:0.1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5 CLOSE:) italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start age POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$t_{\rm acc}$}}\sim(0.1-0.5)\hbox{{$t_{\rm age}$}} using the best-fitting values or a 95% upper limit of taccâˆ¼(0.3-0.6)â¢tagesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘¡acc0.30.6subscriptğ‘¡ageitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start acc POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( NUMBER:0.3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6 CLOSE:) italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start age POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$t_{\rm acc}$}}\sim(0.3-0.6)\hbox{{$t_{\rm age}$}}; NGC 5044 actually has smaller values, but if the second bin is included (which has intrinsic absorption just as significant as the inner bin) then taccsubscriptğ‘¡accitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start acc POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{\rm acc}â€‰ is consistent with the values quoted above. These accumulation timescales are a sizeable fraction of tagesubscriptğ‘¡ageitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start age POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{\rm age}, and thus Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ within the central bin(s) can account for most, if not all, of the mass deposited by the cooling flow over the lifetime of the flow; the exact value depends on precisely when the cooling flow begins and whether MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M}â€‰ varies with time.

The total absorbing masses have large errors within the 95% confidence limits. Although the best-fitting values for taccsubscriptğ‘¡accitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start acc POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{\rm acc}â€‰ are typically larger than tagesubscriptğ‘¡ageitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start age POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{\rm age}, the 95% lower limits are â‰²tageless-than-or-similar-toabsentsubscriptğ‘¡ageRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start age POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lesssim\hbox{{$t_{\rm age}$}} for all but NGC 4472. We reiterate that we consider these values at the largest radius to be less secure than the central bin(s) because the fits do not clearly require the addition of the oxygen edge outside the inner 1-2 bins. Nevertheless, the result for NGC 4472 is striking and deserves comment. Clearly the approximation of a spherically symmetric, relaxed cooling flow is invalid for Râ‰³3â¢â€²greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘…3â€²italic-R RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:3 â€²R\gtrsim 3\arcmin because the isophotal distortions suggest a strong interaction with the surrounding Virgo gas (Irwin & Sarazin, 1996) and thus the estimate of MË™Ë™ğ‘€OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\dot{M}â€‰ unlikely applies at larger radii. If the large value of Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ at large radius is confirmed then another mechanism must have produced the warm gas in NGC 4472.

Hence, within the central 1-2 bins (Râˆ¼10-20similar-toğ‘…1020italic-R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:20R\sim 10-20 kpc) where the model constraints are most secure we conclude that the absorbing mass inferred from the oxygen edges can explain most (and perhaps all) of the mass deposited by a cooling flow over the age of the system. If the edges also apply at larger radii (as we have assumed), then all of the deposited mass (except for NGC 4472) can be easily explained by the inferred absorbing mass. These qualitative conclusions still apply if the oxygen edge optical depths are really closer to their 95% lower limits as discussed near the top of this section.

We mention that systems without strong cooling flows will not have had sufficient time to accumulate the âˆ¼109â¢Mâ˜‰similar-toabsentsuperscript109subscriptğ‘€â˜‰RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{9}\hbox{{$M_{\sun}$}} within Râˆ¼1â¢â€²similar-toğ‘…1â€²italic-R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 â€²R\sim 1\arcmin to produce detectable soft X-ray emission. Thus, the â€œVery Soft Componentsâ€ found in galaxies with low ratios of X-ray to optical luminosity unlikely arise from warm gas deposited in a cooling flow and instead probably reflect the collective emission from X-ray binaries (e.g., Irwin & Bregman 1999).

section.h3: 5.4 Constraints from the Optical and FUV

div.p: Since collisionally ionized gas at temperatures of 105-6superscript1056NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{5-6} K emits many strong lines at optical and ultraviolet wavelengths (e.g., Pistinner & Sarazin 1994; Voit & Donahue 1995), we consider whether the large amounts of absorbing material implied by the intrinsic X-ray absorption (Table 2) violate published constraints on line emission in the optical and UV spectral regions. The best published constraints available in the optical are for HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha from studies of extended ionized gas in the centers of elliptical galaxies (e.g., Trinchieri & di Alighieri 1991; Goudfrooij et al 1994; Macchetto et al 1996). In most cases the emission line gas is only detected within râ‰²20â¢â€³less-than-or-similar-toğ‘Ÿ20â€³italic-r RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:20 â€³r\lesssim 20\arcsec which is significantly smaller than the central 1â¢â€²1â€²NUMBER:1 â€²1\arcmin used in our analysis.

The object in our sample where HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha has been detected out to the largest angular radius is NGC 5044. Macchetto et al (1996) measure Fâ¢(Hâ¢Î±)=1.4Ã—10-13FHğ›¼1.4superscript1013F OPEN:( H italic-alpha CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.4 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:13 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rm F(H\alpha)=1.4\times 10^{-13} erg cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}â€‰within R=0.5â¢â€²ğ‘…0.5â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5 â€²R=0.5\arcmin. We can estimate the temperature at which the HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha emission implied by Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ (Table 2) within R=1.0â¢â€²ğ‘…1.0â€²italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.0 â€²R=1.0\arcmin equals the observed flux. We take the predicted HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha line intensity at peak temperature from Pistinner & Sarazin and the temperature dependence of âˆ¼T-2.5similar-toabsentsuperscriptğ‘‡2.5RELOP:similar-to italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim T^{-2.5} from inspection of Figure 7 of Voit & Donahue. After accounting for the different region sizes we find that the required temperature is â‰ˆ1.5Ã—105absent1.5superscript105RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\approx 1.5\times 10^{5} K using the best-fitting Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}, although when using the 95% lower limit on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ we find that Tâ‰ˆ0.5Ã—105ğ‘‡0.5superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 0.5\times 10^{5} K.

Similar results hold for NGC 1399, 4472, and 4649 although the comparison is less certain because of the larger aperture corrections. If no aperture correction is made for NGC 5044 then the implied temperatures rise to Tâ‰ˆ2.5Ã—105ğ‘‡2.5superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 2.5\times 10^{5} K at best fit and Tâ‰ˆ1.7Ã—105ğ‘‡1.7superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.7 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 1.7\times 10^{5} K at the 95% lower limit. If we consider also that Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ in Table 2 is over-estimated because the oxygen abundance is larger than solar (âˆ¼1.5â¢Zâ˜‰Â similar-toabsent1.5Zâ˜‰Â RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.5 italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 1.5\hbox{{$Z_{\sun}$\thinspace}} â€“ see PAPER2) and carbon and nitrogen contribute âˆ¼40%similar-toabsentpercent40RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:40 POSTFIX:percent\sim 40\% to the measured optical depths (Â§5.3), we obtain Tâ‰ˆ1.8Ã—105ğ‘‡1.8superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.8 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 1.8\times 10^{5} K at best fit and Tâ‰ˆ1.2Ã—105ğ‘‡1.2superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 1.2\times 10^{5} K at the 95% lower limit (again without aperture correction). Therefore, the published constraints on HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha are satisfied if Tâ‰³2.0Ã—105greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘‡2.0superscript105italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:2.0 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\gtrsim 2.0\times 10^{5} K.

Stronger lines from warm gas are expected to appear in the UV, but Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope (HUT) observations detected no significant emission lines in NGC 1399, 4472, and 4649 (Ferguson et al 1991; Brown, Ferguson, & Davidsen 1995). It is unfortunate that the strongest emission lines for temperatures Tâˆ¼(2-3)Ã—105similar-toğ‘‡23superscript105italic-T RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim(2-3)\times 10^{5} K are Oâ€‰v(1218Ã…), Oâ€‰vi(1034Ã…), and Nâ€‰v(1240Ã…) which appear to be lost in the background geocoronal emission (e.g., Figure 1 of Ferguson et al 1991, though see below for O vi). However, the lines Câ€‰iv(1549Ã…), Oâ€‰iv(1401Ã…), and Neâ€‰iv(1602Ã…) are also strong and uncontaminated by geocoronal emission.

To determine the gas temperature at which, e.g., the Oâ€‰iv(1401Ã…) flux would not violate the published UV constraints we estimate that the Oâ€‰ivâ€‰ flux would have to be less than âˆ¼10%similar-toabsentpercent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTFIX:percent\sim 10\% of the continuum considering the error bars on the spectrum of NGC 1399 (Figure 2 of Ferguson et al 1991). This limit corresponds to a flux of âˆ¼1.4Ã—10-12similar-toabsent1.4superscript1012RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.4 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1.4\times 10^{-12} erg cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}â€‰. We take the predicted Oâ€‰ivâ€‰ line intensity at peak temperature from Pistinner & Sarazin and assume the temperature gradient above the peak falls similarly to that displayed for Câ€‰ivâ€‰ in Figure 7 of Voit & Donahue. Using the best-fitting Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ (and accounting for the smaller HUT aperture) we find that a temperature of at least 3Ã—1053superscript105NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3\times 10^{5} K is required, though the 95% lower limits on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}(which are probably more realistic â€“ Â§3.6.3) coupled with the oxygen abundance and C/N issues as above indicate the limit is more conservatively âˆ¼2Ã—105similar-toabsent2superscript105RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 2\times 10^{5} K. Similar limits are obtained for the other lines and for the HUT spectra of NGC 4472 and 4649 (Brown et al, 1995).

Our procedure of requiring the line fluxes to be less than 10% of the continuum may result in limits that are too restrictive. Dixon et al (1996) have estimated 2â¢Ïƒ2ğœNUMBER:2 italic-sigma2\sigma upper limits on the Oâ€‰vi(1034Ã…) intensity from M87 which has a HUT spectrum very similar to NGC 1399. Their 2â¢Ïƒ2ğœNUMBER:2 italic-sigma2\sigma upper limit on the Oâ€‰viâ€‰ flux within a 1â¢â€²1â€²NUMBER:1 â€²1\arcmin circle is âˆ¼1Ã—10-10similar-toabsent1superscript1010RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1\times 10^{-10} erg cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}â€‰. If the warm gas has a temperature of 3.2Ã—1053.2superscript105NUMBER:3.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3.2\times 10^{5} K corresponding to the peak temperature for Oâ€‰vi, then the observed limit is comparable to the Oâ€‰viâ€‰ emission expected from the warm gas of NGC 1399 when using the 95% lower limit on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}. Hence, if the HUT results for M87 apply to NGC 1399 (as they appear to), then the predicted Oâ€‰viâ€‰ emission agrees with the limits, especially if the temperature is not precisely at the peak temperature for Oâ€‰vi.

Although the hypothesis of warm, mostly collisionally ionized, gas apparently can explain the X-ray observations and the matter deposited by the cooling flows, this model has serious theoretical difficulties which must be overcome before it can be considered a viable model:

Twarm<Tvirialsubscriptğ‘‡warmsubscriptğ‘‡virialitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start warm POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start virial POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm warm}<T_{\rm virial}. The temperature of the warm gas (â‰²0.1less-than-or-similar-toabsent0.1RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.1\lesssim 0.1 keV) is less than the virial temperatures of the halos (âˆ¼1similar-toabsent1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\sim 1 keV) implying the gas is not thermally supported. How does the warm gas support itself in the gravitational fields of these systems?

tcoolwarmâ¢gasâ‰ªtcoolhotâ¢gasmuch-less-thansuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡coolwarmgassuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡coolhotgasitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start warm gas POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-less-than italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start hot gas POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endt_{\rm cool}^{\rm warm\,gas}\ll t_{\rm cool}^{\rm hot\,gas}. The cooling time of the warm gas is very short, even more so than the hot gas in the central regions. How are large quantities of gas maintained at these temperatures?

Most likely these problems can only be solved with a substantial modification of the standard cooling flow scenario. Clearly an additional energy source and very possibly the important role of magnetic fields will have to be considered. A small number of models have been proposed throughout the years which consider these issues, though they are not well developed and do not at present make detailed predictions regarding the issues (1) and (2) above. These models have generally been designed to completely suppress cooling flows, and thus will have to be modified to allow some cooling of the hot gas. We now briefly review some of the candidate models.

Binney (1996) and Ciotti & Ostriker (2000) have proposed feedback from the central black hole as a promising means of inhibiting the cooling of hot gas in the central regions of galactic cooling flows. In this model whenever the black hole accretes a sufficient amount of gas to stimulate nuclear activity, the accompanying radiation stimulated by the accretion heats up the hot gas and prevents further cooling. This is supposed to be a cyclical process such that the AGN phase is sufficiently rare to be consistent with the lack of nuclear activity in most cooling flows. If the AGN feedback energy does not completely suppress cooling of the hot gas but instead merely prevents most of the gas from cooling down to temperatures below 105-6superscript1056NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{5-6} K, this might be able to explain issues (1) and (2). We also note that most of the cooling gas is not expected to reach the central black hole in standard models (Brighenti & Mathews, 1999).

Another energy source proposed to exist in the centers of cooling flows is that from the reconnection of tangled magnetic field lines. It has been known for some time that small seed magnetic fields can be amplified within a cooling flow to produce sizeable fields at the centers (e.g., Soker & Sarazin 1990; Lesch & Bender 1990; Moss & Shukurov 1996; Mathews & Brighenti 1997). Zoabi et al (1998) show that reconnection energy can significantly reduce the cooling rates and may account for significant amounts of warm (T=105-6ğ‘‡superscript1056italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT=10^{5-6} K) gas. Similarly, Norman & Meiksen (1996) propose a two-phase model to recycle warm and hot gas along magnetic flux loops also resulting in much lower rates of mass deposition.

Both the AGN and magnetic field reconnection models would explain the warm gas phase as a non-equilibrium configuration where the warm gas is continuously diluted by heating processes and replenished by cooling from the hot phase. If we consider the (unlikely) possibility that the warm gas is a long-lived equilibrium phase (see, e.g., Fabian 1996) then magnetic pressure is probably the most viable non-thermal process which can support the gas. Mathews & Brighenti (1999) describe a possible equilibrium model of the warm gas as the the outer envelopes of low mass stars forming in a cooling flow.

The details of how the magnetic field would support the gas are uncertain. Daines et al (1994) suggest that the cool gas blobs would be anchored to the hot gas by the magnetic fields, and thus the pressure support would actually come from the hot gas. However, inspection of Table 2 reveals that Mabsâˆ¼(1-10)â¢Mhotsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘€abs110subscriptğ‘€hotitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10 CLOSE:) italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start hot POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$M_{\rm abs}$}}\sim(1-10)\hbox{{$M_{\rm hot}$}} within the central bins indicating that the hot gas could not support the cool gas. (The 95% lower limits on Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}are considered here.) At larger radii it may be possible for the hot gas to support the cool gas.

Whatever the details of the magnetic support the condition of hydrostatic equilibrium requires that B2âˆ¼6â¢Mabsâ¢Gâ¢Mgravâ¢r-4similar-tosuperscriptğµ26subscriptğ‘€absğºsubscriptğ‘€gravsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ4italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:6 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-G italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start grav POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endB^{2}\sim 6\hbox{{$M_{\rm abs}$}}GM_{\rm grav}r^{-4}. Using the values for Mabssubscriptğ‘€absitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start abs POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm abs}â€‰ within the central 1â¢â€²1â€²NUMBER:1 â€²1\arcmin bin quoted in Table 2 and the gravitating masses obtained from previous ROSAT studies (David et al 1995; Kim & Fabbiano 1995; Rangarajan et al 1995; Irwin & Sarazin 1996) we find that Bâˆ¼100â¢Î¼â¢Gsimilar-toğµ100ğœ‡Gitalic-B RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100 italic-mu GB\sim 100\mu\rm G is required within a 5 kpc radius.

Estimates of the magnetic field strengths from radio polarization analyses of these galaxies are lacking, although there exist estimates using minimum energy arguments for NGC 1399 (Killeen et al, 1988), NGC 4472 (Ekers & Kotanyi, 1977), and NGC 4649 (Stanger & Warwick, 1986) which give consistent results: Bâ‰³50-100â¢Î¼â¢Ggreater-than-or-equivalent-toğµ50100ğœ‡Gitalic-B RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:50 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:100 italic-mu GB\gtrsim 50-100\mu\rm G at the centers and Bâ‰³(5-10)â¢Î¼â¢Ggreater-than-or-equivalent-toğµ510ğœ‡Gitalic-B RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to OPEN:( NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10 CLOSE:) italic-mu GB\gtrsim(5-10)\mu\rm G at râˆ¼0.5â¢â€²similar-toğ‘Ÿ0.5â€²italic-r RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 â€²r\sim 0.5\arcmin. Assuming Bâˆ¼r-1.2similar-toğµsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ1.2italic-B RELOP:similar-to italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endB\sim r^{-1.2} (Mathews & Brighenti, 1997) then these observations imply âŸ¨BâŸ©âˆ¼5â¢Î¼â¢Gsimilar-todelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğµ5ğœ‡GOPEN:langle italic-B CLOSE:rangle RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:5 italic-mu G\langle B\rangle\sim 5\mu\rm G when averaged over a 1â¢â€²1â€²NUMBER:1 â€²1\arcmin circle. Since the observations only set lower limits the expected âŸ¨BâŸ©âˆ¼100â¢Î¼â¢Gsimilar-todelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğµ100ğœ‡GOPEN:langle italic-B CLOSE:rangle RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100 italic-mu G\langle B\rangle\sim 100\mu\rm G fields are consistent with the observations.

Interestingly, the need for Bâˆ¼100â¢Î¼â¢Gsimilar-toğµ100ğœ‡Gitalic-B RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100 italic-mu GB\sim 100\mu\rm G in cooling flows has been suggested by Brighenti & Mathews (1997) on entirely different grounds. In their analysis of the gravitating mass distributions of NGC 4472, 4636, and 4649 Brighenti & Mathews (1997) find in every case that the gravitating mass determined from the X-ray analysis falls below that estimated from stellar dynamics for râ‰²(few)â¢kpcless-than-or-similar-toğ‘Ÿfewkpcitalic-r RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to OPEN:( few CLOSE:) kpcr\lesssim(\rm few)kpc. If Bâˆ¼100â¢Î¼â¢Gsimilar-toğµ100ğœ‡Gitalic-B RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100 italic-mu GB\sim 100\mu\rm G within the centers of these systems then the X-ray and stellar dynamical masses agree. (A similar result holds for NGC 1399 as well â€“ W. Mathews 2000, private communication.)

Finally, we mention it may be useful to consider a model for the warm gas that does not originate from cooling out of the hot phase. One such possibility is offered by the material continuously ejected by the stars. This material is injected into the ISM with low energy and is shock-heated up to the virial temperature of the halo. Although theoretical arguments suggest that the heating is very rapid (Mathews, 1990), more detailed calculations are required to rule out the possibility that in fact the transition is gradual and could give rise to an observable phase of warm gas consistent with the X-ray observations.

From deprojection analysis of the ROSAT PSPC data of 10 cooling flow galaxies and groups with low Galactic columns we have detected oxygen absorption at the 2â¢Ïƒ/3â¢Ïƒ2ğœ3ğœNUMBER:2 italic-sigma MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 italic-sigma2\sigma/3\sigma level intrinsic to the central âˆ¼1â¢â€²similar-toabsent1â€²RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 â€²\sim 1\arcmin in half of the sample: NGC 507, 1399, 4472, 4649, and 5044. The data for the other systems are insufficient to place interesting constraints on the absorption profile but are consistent with substantial absorption. We modeled the oxygen absorption as a single edge (rest frame E=0.532ğ¸0.532italic-E RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.532E=0.532 keV) which produces the necessary absorption in both the PSPC and ASCA data for Eâ‰³0.5greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ¸0.5italic-E RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:0.5E\gtrsim 0.5 keV without violating the PSPC constraints over 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 âˆ¼0.4similar-toabsent0.4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4\sim 0.4 keV for which no significant excess absorption is indicated. Assuming the absorber is collisionally ionized gas we infer a temperature of 105-6superscript1056NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{5-6} K from consideration of the possible edge energies consistent with the PSPC data.

The intrinsic oxygen absorption reconciles the longstanding problem of why negligible column densities for a foreground absorber with solar abundances were inferred from ROSAT data whereas large columns were obtained from ASCA and other instruments with bandpasses above âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV. Moreover, since the absorption is confined to energies above âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 keV there is no need for large columns of cold H which are known to be very inconsistent with the negligible atomic and molecular H measured in galactic and cluster cooling flows (e.g., Bregman et al 1992; Oâ€™Dea et al 1994).

In most of the galaxies and groups we have found that single-phase and cooling flow models cannot explain the X-ray emission in the soft (0.2-0.4 keV) energy channels of the ROSAT PSPC data (Â§3.6.3). That is, when NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ of the standard absorber model is freely fitted it is found that NH<NHGalsubscriptğ‘Hsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘HGalitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start Gal POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}$}}<\hbox{{$N_{\rm H}^{\rm Gal}$}} in the central bins of most systems, with NGC 4472 and NGC 5044 showing the most significant soft excesses. If we model this soft emission as coronal gas we obtain temperatures 105-6superscript1056NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{5-6} K in excellent agreement with those inferred from the energy ranges of the absorption edges.

Hence, the sub-Galactic column densities are consistent with a direct detection of the emission from the intrinsic absorbing gas. The agreement between the temperatures inferred from the emission and absorbing properties of the warm gas lends strong support to the ionized gas model. In contrast, dust can not explain the excess soft X-ray emission. (Other problems exist with the dust hypothesis â€“ see Â§5.1.)

Our simple estimates of the amount of absorbing matter implied by our single-edge absorption measurements are consistent with the total amount of matter expected to have been deposited by a cooling flow (Â§5.3). With the arrival of higher quality data from Chandra and XMM more accurate estimates should be made which account for a range of absorbing edges and possible radiative transfer effects in the warm gas.

We have examined the theoretical difficulties associated with attributing the absorption to warm ionized gas and have discussed some candidate models that may be able to account for these problems. Future detailed calculations are required to assess the viability of these models (Â§5.5).

Fortunately on the observational front it will be very easy to verify the intrinsic oxygen absorption with new Chandra and XMM data. The XMM (EPIC) and Chandra (ACIS-S) CCDs both extend down to 0.1-0.2 keV and have substantially better energy resolution than the PSPC. Observations with these instruments can easily test our prediction for warm gas in both absorption and emission. The grating spectrometers of XMM and Chandra have even better energy resolution (but smaller effective area) and, in principle, might detect individual edges.

We emphasize that the absorption signature of the warm gas is expected to be a relatively broad trough over energies 0.4âˆ¼0.8similar-to0.40.8NUMBER:0.4 RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.80.4\sim 0.8 keV, and thus future Chandra and XMM observations will not see a single sharp feature. The most straightforward means to confirm our results will be to reproduce the sensitivity of NHsubscriptğ‘Hitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}â€‰ to Eminsubscriptğ¸minitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start min POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{\rm min} for a standard absorber model (Â§3.3). To obtain the properties of the absorber (e.g., temperature and abundances) a model for the soft X-ray opacity such as that described by Krolik & Kallman (1984) must be compared to the new data. In so doing the emission from the warm gas must also be accounted for (Â§3.6.3), and thus it is very important that the detector bandpass extend down to âˆ¼0.1similar-toabsent0.1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1\sim 0.1 keV which it does for the Chandra and XMM CCDs.

As discussed in Â§5.4 optical and FUV constraints imply a lower limit of Tâˆ¼2Ã—105similar-toğ‘‡2superscript105italic-T RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim 2\times 10^{5} K. It is possible that precise measurements of Oâ€‰iii(5007Ã…) could refine this limit, but since this line peaks at Tâˆ¼0.8Ã—105similar-toğ‘‡0.8superscript105italic-T RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.8 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim 0.8\times 10^{5} K its emissivity is already falling rapidly at Tâˆ¼2Ã—105similar-toğ‘‡2superscript105italic-T RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim 2\times 10^{5} K. Future high resolution FUV spectroscopy of the O vi (1034Ã…) line (peak temperature 3.2Ã—1053.2superscript105NUMBER:3.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3.2\times 10^{5} K) with, e.g., FUSE may be able to place additional interesting constraints on the warm gas if its temperature does not exceed Tâ‰ˆ5Ã—105ğ‘‡5superscript105italic-T RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\approx 5\times 10^{5} K.

It should be remembered that to infer the properties of the warm gas from X-ray observations the absorption and emission spectrum arising from warm gas must be disentangled from Galactic absorption and the emission from hot plasma. Since (if confirmed) the warm gas almost certainly represents the mass deposited by an inhomogeneous cooling flow (Â§5.3), the hot gas at each radius should also emit over a range of temperatures. Hence, the thermodynamic state of the X-ray emitting plasma appears to be very complex in the central regions of the (X-ray) brightest galaxies and groups, and the analogous results for A1795 presented in PAPER1 suggest the same applies for galaxy clusters.
